_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Methylamines, derived from methanol and ammonia, and various amines, derived from higher alcohols and ammonia, are produced at the Taminco site.  In addition, DIMLA is produced from dimethylamine and formaldehyde 37% solution.  Some of the compounds handled are considered hazardous by EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  We insist on strict adherence to safety precautions developed to prevent human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal safety and health, as well as the safety and health of our coworkers and minimize the threat to our community and the environment.  Our safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the proper maintenance of the safety systems designed in these facilities, the procedures used by our personnel and the training of these personnel.  



As a American Chemistry Council Member, our safety programs are in compliance with Responsible Care.  Our emergency response plan, which is based on OSHA's HAZWOPER and Fire Brigade regulations, contains procedures for notification of the local Emergency Management Authority, local fire department, and potentially affected neighbors.  Neighbor notification is by a network of sirens surrounding the plant site, which can be activated by either Plant personnel or the local Fire Department.



    This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Plan regulation (40CFR, Part 68). The substances and processes considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the regulation.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:



    The primary purpose of this facility is to convert ammonia and alcohols into a variety of chemical intermediates including methylamines and higher amines.  All products are used by our customers in the production of other compounds. The s

ite is equipped to load and unload rail cars and trucks.  This facility stores liquid ammonia. 



    The regulated substances handled at this facility include Ammonia and Formaldehyde, which are defined by the EPA as toxic, and various flammables including: Dimethylamine, Isopropylamine, Methylamine and Trimethylamine. The maximum amounts of these substances stored at this facility follow: 



Process Storage:

     4,000,000 pounds of Ammonia

     5,100,000 pounds of Dimethylamine

     2,600,000 pounds of Methylamine

     2,100,000 pounds of Trimethylamine

     3,500,000 pounds of Isopropylamine

        63,000 pounds of Formaldehyde



Railcar Storage*:



     9,120,000 pounds of Dimethylamine

     6,400,000 pounds of Methylamine

     5,600,000 pounds of Trimethylamine

     3,680,000 pounds of Isopropylamine

       800,000 pounds of NH3 crude/NH3 solutions from process shutdowns to be reworked into process

             

Total Storage:

     4,000,000 pounds of Ammonia

    14,220,000 pounds of Dimethylamine

     9,000,000 pounds of Methylamine

     7,700,000 pounds of Trimethylamine

     7,180,000 pounds of Isopropylamine

        63,000 pounds of Formaldehyde

       800,000 pounds of NH3 crude/NH3 solutions from process shutdowns to be reworked into process



*The amount of railcar storage is based upon the maximum number of railcars on site at a time and the size of the railcars as follows:

     57 railcars of Dimethylamine (160,000 lbs each)

     40 railcars of Methylamine (160,000 lbs each)

     35 railcars of Trimethylamine (160,000 lbs each)

     23 railcars of Isopropylamine (160,000 lbs each)

     10 railcars of NH3 crude/NH3 solutions from process shutdowns to be reworked into process (160,000 lbs each)

        Ammonia and Formaldehyde are not received by railcar.





The General Accident Prevention Program and Specific Program Steps:



    The facility developed prevention program elements based on the EPA's Accidental Release P

revention Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation. This facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes. 



Five-year Accident History:



   There were no RMP incidents in the past 5 years.



The Emergency Response Program:



     The facility's emergency response program is based on OSHA's HAZWOPER standard. At this site, employees are trained to recognize emergencies and initiate emergency response from outside agencies. All employees have been trained to OSHA's First Responder Awareness Level. The plant also has a Emergency Services Team, who are trained to the HAZMAT Technician or HAZMAT Specialist levels of the OSHA's HAZWOPER standard and OSHA Fire Brigade - NFPA 600 Advanced Exterior Fire Fighting. All employees receive annual refresher training in the emergency plan. Emergency response activities have been coordinated with the Santa Rosa County Emergency Management Agency and the Pace Fire Department. Periodic drills are conducted with these agencies to review the effectiveness of our emergency plans. Periodic planning and communications meetings are held with the Pace Fire Department, Santa Rosa County Emergency Management and the LEPC.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



     Plant hazards reviews, risk analyses or incident reviews are among the systems we rely on to drive safety improvements. At this time there are no major administrative, operational, process or equipment changes planned for the facility.
